title: POERUP - Policies for OER Uptake

author: Rory McGreal, UNESCO Chair on Open Educational Resources (OER)
Paul Bacsich, Sero Consulting Ltd

Happening with them and Michael Geist at the University of Ottawa leading Open Access component in Canada.
He said last year despite the mounting support for Open Access, Canada is lagged behind.
With only a handful of pilot projects from the federally funded research agencies.
And he calls for it's time for them to make a firm commitment to Open Access.
And in fact, that is happening.
This was about a year and a half ago, and in fact now our funding agencies are supporting Open Access.
One of the problems in Canada is that.
I think it's the only country in the world that does not have a national educational authority.
All education is controlled by the provinces and territories, so there's 14 different governments in Canada all working on education independently.
So there's no government policies.
There's few initiatives and I'll talk about the big one that came up there.

Have been policy proposals in in different higher education institutions and the one open lead that Canada the federal government has done is not in education because they're not allowed to even use the word education in any of their documents.
Is open data and there's a big movement in Canada for innovation and leveraging public information by opening up the data, developing computer products, etc.
Research, etc.
There was a big Canadian split and it's the first time it happened.
In Canada.
Is the 14 Council of Ministers of Education.
When the open Declaration came out of Paris, the K12 didn't support it.
And the higher Ed supported it right across.
Usually it splits by province that Alberta will refuse, or Québec will refuse.
Or but this time it was a split.
All the higher education institutions supported it, and the K12 didn't and there was a huge debate about it.
And finally at the meeting last June they did Decatur.
12 said they supported it as long as we don't have to do anything.
The they supported it, but sort of very reluctantly.

They are committed to putting together so that was the first major education research initiative in.
Canada.

And so we're very happy about this.
We've been lobbying our politicians for about 2 1/2 years in order to get to this state, so it's a major development.
In Canada and the three Western provinces have signed a memorandum of understanding to share and to work together in promoting open educational resource is so.

Again, this is a major development in Canada and it's changed Michael Guy's view that nothing is happening, that something really is happening and it's in the West and it is interesting that it's also the Western United States that's leading with California, Washington State and Utah.
Where this is coming?

The other aspect is that there are four sorry, now five members of the Open Education Resource, Universitas Initiative in Canada, and they again they're all in the West and their outlined here 2 in British Columbia and and three in Alberta.
And again it ties in with our support.
For open Education resource is.

I have to mention about Ontario, which is Canada's largest province, about 1/3 of the population live in Ontario and they just put out a call for proposals for course development and they did not insist on an open license on it.
And this was a big disappointment to us and we had discussions with them, but they just wouldn't wouldn't listen to any advice and this is particularly sad because.

Ariel had an experience about 10 years ago with karaokes of creating license content and it was never shared and the reason it was never shared is it was too difficult to figure out the licenses of where who could use what and how, and what the permissions were in everything.
And we know that and we have lessons learned from that and we have researched that shows that and we showed it to them again, but again they're repeating the same mistakes that were made in the past.

And the other big initiative non initiative is Québec, which is our francophone area and they seem more interested in protecting their local publishers than in opening up, and in fact they've been one of the biggest.
Opponents of openness in Canada, and I think that's a shame for the rest of Canada, but they have a very close view of how to protect their cultural industries in Québec.
Bill C 11.

It's been really opening up our fair dealing in Canada.
It includes education and fair dealing.
It expands the conditions that says large and liberal interpretation of Fair dealing.

The logo for website all the rest of it.

Courses are some very solid reporting in the Pirate Wiki.
It might sink back into the under wiki, which is the traditional Rebecca Biscuit Wiki, which still exists in distance learning.
We have to make some decisions.
We'd rather make them with you rather than just say, well, that's it.
Of course, it will last for a year or two, because that's expected by the Commission, but I'm trying to encourage something a little bit more active.
It's so easy for things just to stop.
They will be licensed so people can take them forward of course, but so if anyone has any thoughts that hasn't talked to me then we're open to these discussions.
I think then that's that's the point.
I want to make about how this goes forward and what collaborations might still be ongoing, but that's that's it for me, and that's it, from Rory, and hopefully we have a little time for questions.
